sn22.153:4.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn22.153:4.3: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’?”
sn22.153:4.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn22.153:4.5: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn22.153:4.6: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.153:4.10: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn22.153:4.11: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.153:4.12: What do you think, mendicants? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn22.153:4.14: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.153:4.16: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn22.153:4.17: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’?”
sn22.153:4.24: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.153:4.26: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn22.153:4.27: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’?”
sn22.153:4.30: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
